banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: The reporting system that sexual assault survivors want
videoData.socialTitle: The reporting system that sexual assault survivors want

recommendations.blurb: Check out more resources on sexual assault, curated by Jessica Ladd.

recItems.blurb: In the paper, Ayres and Unkovic explore the potential applications of information escrows for social good, from a game theory and legal perspective.
recItems.headline: Information Escrows
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE
recItems.note:
Ian Ayres and Kate Unkovic
Yale Law School, 2012

recItems.blurb: This documentary paints a stark picture of campus sexual assault and chronicles the growth of the advocacy moment that has brought the issue to the national stage. While criticized as presenting a biased picture of campus assault and the response of universities, the film does provide quite a bit of information about the topic to those interested in learning more.
recItems.headline: *The Hunting Ground*
recItems.label: WATCH

recItems.blurb: Unsafe in the Ivory Tower provides a good overview of male-on-female campus sexual assault. Published in 2009, the book does not contain data from some more recent studies, but most of what is covered still holds true today.
recItems.headline: Unsafe in the Ivory Tower
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Bonnie Fisher, Francis T. Cullen, and Leah E. Daigle
SAGE Publications, Inc, 2009

recItems.blurb: A blog post describing some of the research that went behind the creation of Callisto, the online sexual assault reporting system that Ladd describes in her talk.
recItems.headline: Do Survivors Want Callisto?
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

takeAction.blurb: **Donate** to Callisto and directly assist in the development of technology to combat sexual assault and harassment.
**Nominate** a college to adopt the sexual assault reporting system Callisto. The more nominations a school gets, the higher priority they'll be for outreach.

nodes.whoTheyAre: Jessica Ladd is using technology to combat sexual assault, empower survivors and advance justice.
nodes.whyListen:
Jessica Ladd is the founder of Callisto, formerly Sexual Health Innovations, and a TED Fellow. She has been honored as a fearless changemaker by the Case Foundation, an emerging innovator by Ashoka and American Express, and as the Civic Hacker of the Year by Baltimore Innovation Week.

Before founding Sexual Health Innovations, Ladd worked in the White House Office of National AIDS Policy as a public policy associate at The AIDS Institute and as a sexual health educator and researcher for a variety of organizations. She also founded The Social Innovation Lab in Baltimore and a chapter of FemSex at Pomona College. She received her Masters in Public Health at Johns Hopkins and her BA in Public Policy/Human Sexuality at Pomona College. She left a PhD program in infectious disease epidemiology at Johns Hopkins in order to pursue work at Sexual Health Innovations full-time.

Ladd has created a platform, Callisto, for survivors of sexual assault to electronically document and report what happened to them. The platform helps identify serial sexual offenders, allowing victims to either (1) directly report to an institution or (2) store their identity in escrow and only release it to an institution if another victim names the same assailant.

videoData.description: We don't have to live in a world where 99 percent of rapists get away with it, says TED Fellow Jessica Ladd. With Callisto, a new platform for college students to confidentially report sexual assault, Ladd is helping survivors get the support and justice they deserve while respecting their privacy concerns. "We can create a world where there's a real deterrent to violating the rights of another human being," she says.
videoData.socialDescription: We don't have to live in a world where 99 percent of rapists get away with it, says TED Fellow Jessica Ladd. With Callisto, a new platform for college students to confidentially report sexual assault, Ladd is helping survivors get the support and justice they deserve while respecting their privacy concerns. "We can create a world where there's a real deterrent to violating the rights of another human being," she says.

Ladd","thumb":"https://pi.tedcdn.com/r/talkstar-photos.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/318627b9-2cf2-455b-8b25-2c13c2de6e5d/JessicaLadd_2016F-embed.jpg?quality=89&w=600","slug":"jessica_ladd_the_reporting_system_that_sexual_assault_survivors_want","event":"TED2016","published":1458140198,"external":{"service":"YouTube","code":"orumugzJpt0","duration":360.0,"start_time":0.0}}

cues.text: Hannah is excited to be going to college.

She couldn't wait
to get out of her parents' house,
to prove to them that she's an adult,

and to prove to her new friends
that she belongs.
She heads to a campus party

where she sees a guy
that she has a crush on.
Let's call him Mike.

The next day, Hannah wakes up
with a pounding headache.

She can only remember
the night in flashes.
But what she does remember is

throwing up in the hall
outside Mike's room

and staring at the wall silently
while he was inside her,
wanting it to stop,
then shakily stumbling home.
She doesn't feel good about what happened,

but she thinks, "Maybe this is just
what sex in college is?"

One in five women and one in 13 men
will be sexually assaulted

at some point during their college career
in the United States.

Less than 10 percent will ever report
their assault to their school
or to the police.

And those who do, on average,
wait 11 months to make the report.

Hannah initially just feels like dealing
with what happened on her own.

But when she sees Mike
taking girls home from parties,
she's worried about them.
After graduation, Hannah learns

that she was one of five women
who Mike did the exact same thing to.
And this is not an unlikely scenario
because 90 percent of sexual assaults
are committed by repeat offenders.
But with such low reporting rates,

it's fairly unlikely that even
repeat perpetrators will be reported,
much less anything happen if they are.

In fact, only six percent
of assaults reported to the police

end with the assailant
spending a single day in prison.

Meaning, there's a 99 percent chance
that they'll get away with it.

This means there's practically
no deterrent to assault
in the United States.

Now, I'm an infectious disease
epidemiologist by training.
I'm interested in systems and networks

and where we can concentrate
our resources to do the most good.

So this, to me, is a tragic
but a solvable problem.

So when the issue of campus assault
started hitting the news a few years ago,

it felt like a unique opportunity
to make a change.
And so we did.

We started by talking
to college survivors.

And what they wish they'd had
in college is pretty simple;
they wanted a website,

one they could use
at the time and place
that felt safest to them

with clearly written information
about their reporting options,

with the ability to electronically
report their assault,
rather than having the first step

to go in and talk to someone
who may or may not believe them.

With the option to create
a secure, timestamped document
of what happened to them,

preserving evidence
even if they don't want to report yet.
And lastly, and perhaps most critically,
with the ability to report their assault

only if someone else
reported the same assailant.

You see, knowing that you weren't
the only one changes everything.

It changes the way
you frame your own experience,

it changes the way
you think about your perpetrator,
it means that if you do come forward,

you'll have someone else's back
and they'll have yours.

We created a website
that actually does this
and we launched it [...] in August,
on two college campuses.
And we included a unique matching system

where if Mike's first victim
had come forward,

saved her record,
entered into the matching system
and named Mike,

and Mike's second victim
had done the same thing
a few months later,
they would have matched

and the verified contact information
of both survivors

would have been sent
to the authorities at the same time
for investigation and follow up.

If a system like this had existed
for Hannah and her peers,

it's more likely
that they would have reported,
that they would have been believed,

and that Mike would have been
kicked off campus,

gone to jail, or at least
gotten the help that he needed.

And if we were able to stop
repeat offenders like Mike

after just their second assault
following a match,

survivors like Hannah
would never even be assaulted
in the first place.

We could prevent
59 percent of sexual assaults

just by stopping
repeat perpetrators earlier on.

And because we're creating
a real deterrent to assault,
for perhaps the first time,

maybe the Mikes of the world
would never even try to assault anyone.
The type of system I'm describing,
the type of system that survivors want
is a type of information escrow,

meaning an entity that holds on
to information for you
and only releases it to a third party

when certain pre-agreed upon
conditions are met,
such as a match.

The application that we built
is for college campuses.

But the same type of system
could be used in the military
or even the workplace.
We don't have to live in a world

where 99 percent of rapists
get away with it.
We can create one

where those who do wrong
are held accountable,

where survivors get the support
and justice they deserve,

where the authorities
get the information they need,
and where there's a real deterrent

to violating the rights
of another human being.
Thank you.
(Applause)

footnotes.annotation:
While the one in five estimate is doubted by many, study after study has found the same estimate for assault rates among college women.

["Report on the AAU Campus Climate Survey on Sexual Assault and Sexual Misconduct."](https://www.aau.edu/uploadedFiles/AAU_Publications/AAU_Reports/Sexual_Assault_Campus_Survey/AAU_Campus_Climate_Survey_12_14_15.pdf) Association of American Universities, 2015

["Survey of Current and Recent College Students on Sexual Assault."](http://kff.org/other/poll-finding/survey-of-current-and-recent-college-students-on-sexual-assault/) The Washington Post-Kaiser Family Foundation, June 2015

 ["Campus Climate Survey Validation Study."](http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/ccsvsftr.pdf) Bureau of Justice Statistics, January 2016

The one in thirteen statistic has been found across studies, but other national estimates for sexual assault among college men are closer to one in twenty. (The Washington Post-Kaiser Family Foundation, Bureau of Justice Statistics)

There is some evidence that reporting rates have been on the rise in the past couple years, thanks to increased visibility and advocacy around campus sexual assault. Most published peer-reviewed national-level studies rely on data from before 2013, and those find reporting around or below 10 percent. This estimate is mostly gathered from asking only female survivors about reporting, and male survivors tend to be even less likely to report. Reporting rates of college survivors tend to be lower than that of their non-college counterparts, likely in part because college survivors are more likely to know their perpetrator (85 percent do). (Bureau of Justice Statistics)

National Institute of Justice, ["The Campus Sexual Assault (CSA) Study."](https://www.ncjrs.gov/pdffiles1/nij/grants/221153.pdf) Krebs, C., Lindquist, C.H., Warner, T.D., Fisher, B.S., and Martin, S, December 2007

National Institutes of Health, ["Reporting Rape in a National Sample of College Women."](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3211043/pdf/nihms332832.pdf) Wolitzky-Taylor, K.B. et al. 2011

United Educators, ["Confronting Campus Sexual Assault: An Examination of Higher Education Claims."](https://www.bgsu.edu/content/dam/BGSU/human-resources/documents/training/lawroom/Sexual_assault_claim_study.pdf) 2015

Unfortunately, there has only been one real study on sexual assault repeat perpetration, so it is hard to know how valid this estimate is. The study was conducted by Lisak, who asked college men about their perpetration of assault on women and then used the estimated total number of assaults committed by this cohort to figure out how many had been committed by repeat vs. one-time perpetrators. Of note, the estimates of repeat perpetration in the paper are all based around number of assaults committed, not number of people assaulted. No study on what percentage of college students assaulted have been assaulted by repeat perpetrators has even been published, nor has a similar study explored repeat perpetration by women or by men of other men.  

Lisak, D., & Miller, P.M., ["Repeat rape and multiple offending among undetected rapists."](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11991158) *Violence and Victims*, 17(1), 73-84. 2002

This estimate is based off [an analysis by RAINN](https://rainn.org/get-information/statistics/reporting-rates). A peer-reviewed paper by Lonsway and Archambault, published in 2012, puts the figure at 4-14 percent for any kind of incarceration, and 2-7 percent for prison. These estimates are not specific to the reporting of campus assault, and they are focused around forcible rape rather than a more expansive definition of assault. Reported sexual assaults that don’t meet the definition of forcible rape are likely to have an even lower rate of incarceration per reported assault.

Lonsway, K.A., and Archambault, J., ["The 'Justice Gap' for Sexual Assault Cases: Future Directions for Research and Reform."](http://big.assets.huffingtonpost.com/JusticeGappaper.pdf) *Violence Against Women*. 18(2), 145-168. 2012
Based on the earlier estimates: Less than 10 percent reported, 6 percent of these end with the assailant in prison. 99.4 percent go free.

Estimated using data from the Lisak paper.

Lisak, D., & Miller, P.M., ["Repeat rape and multiple offending among undetected rapists."](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11991158) *Violence and Victims*, 17(1), 73-84. 2002
